text: If neurodiversity describes diversity of brains then its meaningless to say an individual is neurodiverse.  The term often used is neurodivergent, but that sort of begs the question of divergent from what.  So I think ideally we'd say neuroatypical, to contrast with neurotypical.

text:
Example:
"The biodiversity in this park is amazing!" = "There are many species in the park."

Hence, neurodiversity means neurological diversity WITHIN A POPULATION.

It doesn't mean, "I'm different from most people."

If you diverge from the norm, you're DIVERGENT, not DIVERSE.

text: @amboinreallife OCD is a psychiatric diagnostic term that refers to an "abnormal" psychological condition. Neurodiversity is a sociological umbrella term that refers to a variety of mental differences in a political rather than clinical way.

text:
It's never about being normal or about empathy and care if you can only please one person by refusing another, so let's change that:

Normalise anecdotes and long-way-round conversations, because one person's personal problems do not mean neurodiversity should stop existing. https://t.co/AfcT9t6FEf

text:
Neurodiversity refers to the fact that no two human brains are exactly alike. The "average" brain, neurological system, or mind is a mathematical average, a composite of traits, that represents no one.  NEUROTYPICAL DOES NOT EXIST BY DEFINITION.

#neurodiversity

text:
Hustleporn does little to account for neurodiversity.
"Show me your habits. I'll tell you your values," for example, is isolating. Some of my habits are induced by anxiety loops and structural disorders.

I can be a hard-working person with strong values and still disassociate.

text: @sei_xe I don't believe in categorizing people into "normal" & "abnormal". Neurodivergence is less common than neurotypicality, but common enough that it's not really accurate to say that we're "different" or "weird". Neurodiversity is everywhere, and calling people abnormal is just rude

text: @DrHlexia The "just" in my thought was in contradistinction to the manipulative baby trope behaviourism sells new parents, so it was helpful to have it affirmed that needs besides food and diaper changes need meeting. But it's still a way of divorcing ND kids from neurodiversity.

text: @DrHlexia The Sears "high needs baby" also papers over neurodiversity in infancy, I think. Spent a *lot* of time telling myself my child was "just high needs" and it wasn't inherently unhelpful because it allowed me to meet sensory an attachment needs as I found them. But also ableist.

text: @adhdeadass From everything I've read, your original statement is, indeed, correct. Neurodiversity refers to a population. You have, in a population, a diverse range of hair styles. Individuals have "uncommon," "atypical," or "divergent of (supposed) normal" hair styles.

text: The neurodiversity paradigm doesn‚Äôt imply that neurotypical people don‚Äôt have problems. It doesn‚Äôt imply neurodivergent people can‚Äôt modify or improve their behaviour. It just pushes back on the assumption that our differences are pathological and diseased. That‚Äôs it.

text: Many people in the neurodiversity movement subscribe to a post-social or holistic model of disability which says that some medical issues might need to be treated or cured while other aspects of disability are best alleviated through social change. This is the revolution, y'all.
tokenized_text: many people in the neurodiversity movement subscribe to a post - social or holistic model of disability which says that some medical issues might need to be treated or cured while other aspects of disability are best alleviated through social change . this is the revolution , you all .

text: There are alternative models of disability. The neurodiversity movement pushes us towards a social model of disability, in which people are disabled by society's negative attitudes and a lack of accomodations. Eg. a person with a wheelchair is disabled by a lack of ramps.
tokenized_text: there are alternative models of disability . the neurodiversity movement pushes us towards a social model of disability , in which people are disabled by society ' s negative attitudes and a lack of accomodations . eg . a person with a wheelchair is disabled by a lack of ramps .

text: The neurodiversity movement does a lot of work to teach people about their disability model - the way that you see disability. In the US, the medical model of disability dominates. Disability is seen as an impairment in the individual which needs medical treatment and cures.
tokenized_text: the neurodiversity movement does a lot of work to teach people about their disability model - the way that you see disability . in the us , the medical model of disability dominates . disability is seen as an impairment in the individual which needs medical treatment and cures .

text: The neurodiversity movement has a political activist branch that works for deinstitutionalization, access to healthcare, access to communication supports (because many neurodivergent people have atypical communication needs such as being nonspeaking and using typing to speak).

text:
Neurodiversity is the FACT that there is natural variation, or diversity, in our neurology. We all have different types of brains.

The neurodiversity paradigm takes this fact and states that diversity in the way our brains work is a benefit to society.

text:
Could autistic, dyslexic, dysgraphic & ADHD workers, known in general to be highly focused, intense, innovative, & creative, be the answer to filling tough-to-fill jobs?

text: There are a number of movements seeking to make reforms in mental health care. The history of abuse and malpractice creates a terrifying dilemma for people who need help. The neurodiversity movement does intersect with these causes, but is distinct in its focus.

text: Neurodiversity is built into the history of autism. People in our community have been abused and treated as subhuman in efforts to make us conform despite our wishes, often using methods such as ABA, which was developed to train animals using physical pain.

text:
The 2 big revelations of the last 6 months:

1) I'm not special. Most of what I experience is part of the general human condition.
2) W/R/T the exceptions to 1, (i.e., my mental illness/neurodiversity, etc.), it's not about fixing. It's about owning and managing.

- Mental illness
- Chronic illness (also known as chronic pain)
